JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MARCH I I, 1955

Prom's Attendance
Less Than Expected
"We were disappointed with the
turnout," jointly stated Mayer
Liebman, president of the Junior
Class, and Jay Yakubisin, president of the Cotillion Board, referring to last week's Junior Prom,
held at Gwynn Oak Park's Dixie
Ball Room.
• "The Cotillion Board co-sponsored the dance with the Junior
Class in order to give the student
body the opportunity to attend
a Social function with a big-name
band. HOwever, the students' response Was so disappointing, that
It is financially
impracticable to
attempt another event of this type.
Although the final figures have not
been tabulated, we estimate a loss
of approximately
$600," commented Yakubisin.
The sponsors borrowed a Johns
Hopkins University banner from
the Alumni
office to use at the
!lance. When last seen, the banDer was still hanging as a
decoration on the wall of the
Dixie Ball
Room. Liebman said,
"We feel
that the person or persons who
took the banner as
a souvenier of
the dance did not
Consider the cost
to the Junior Class and
the Cotillion Board." The banner cost approximately $100.

Military Ball
Ends Month
The Military Ball will be held in
the Homewood Gymnasium on the
evening of March 26, and it will
feature continuous music by the
Second Army Dance Band.
Tickets for the dance will go on
sale March 14 at $2.50, and tables
can be reserved at $2.00 each.
Chairman of the dance. Barrett
Kidner stated that there would be
four hundred and seventy-five tickets on sale, while three hundred
of these reserved for ROTC memtiers. Last year the dance was sold
out a week ahead of time.
Uniforms will be mandatory
dress only for the junior . and
senior members of the ROTC. Underclass members of the ROTC
are urged to\ wear uniforms, but
they are allowed to don formal
dress.
Favors will be given at the
door, and at the "commander's
cotillion" the dates of the sponsor
of the dance and the cadet colonel
will be given flowers, and the dates
of the battalion and company
commander will receive corsages.
As is in keeping with past years,
those attending the dance will not
bring corsages for their dates.
Major Joseph Spinelli is advisor
to this function, and the Pershing
Rifles and the Scabbard and Blade
are co-sponsors.

Scholarships
All Arts and Science, Business, and out of state Engineering students who desire scholarships or wish to renew
scholarships for the next academic- year 1955-1956 make
application with Mrs. Roberts
in Dean Shaffer's Office before
April 15.

—Notice— '
Students interested in a position on the Honor Commission
should send their names and
Post Office box numbers to
Dormitory box number 2018 or
Gilman box number 540. Names
must be submitted before March
15.

Tomorrow, the new Johns
Hopkins University television
series, featuring "the most important and unusual professions
open to career-minded Americans in the wondrous worlds of.
s.eience, industry, and the arts,"
will have its premiere over the
ABC-TV Network and WAAMTV, Baltimore; Saturday, March
26, from 7 to 7:30 p.m.

Doctor McCollum
Receives Award
For Vitamin Work
Dr. Elmer V. McCollum, professor of biochemistry, Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene
and Public Health, has been given
a special Citation of Honor by the
National Dairy Council, the Society
announced.
Dr. McCollum discovered Vitamins A and B1 while teaching at
the University of Wisconsin. After
coming to Hopkins as professor of
biochemistry in 1917, he discovered
Vitamin. D. He is now research
adviser 61 the McCollum-Pratt
fund.
The citation honored Dr. McCollum especially for his discovery of
Vitamin A which "laid the foundation for an appreciation of the importance of dairy foods in human
nutrition."

Annual Sing
Next Week The fourth annual fraternity
sing will be held next Saturday,
March 19, at 8:00 p.m. in the
ROTC Building.
The participating fraternities
will be allotted ten minutes each
in which. they are to sing three
songs. The "Sing" is sponsored by
the Glee CIA and is under the
auspices of Richa-rd Kapp, secretary of the group.
After each fraternity has offered
its vocal selections they will be
judged by a committee of three
consisting of Donald Regier, Glee
Club director; Osmar P. Steinwald, director of alumni relations,
and Dr. Chester WAckwire, Executive Secretary of the Hopkins
"Y". Last year's winners and this
year's defending . champions is
Delta Upsilon.
Any fraternity may enter :the
contest simply by paying a $2
entry fee. At present seven fraternities have entered. They are
Alpha Epsilon Pi, Alpha Tau
Omega, Beta Theta Pi, Delta Upsilon, 'Phi Gamma Delta, Phi
Kappa Psi, and Phi Sigma Delta.
Following the announcement of
the winners, a party will be held
in the ROTC Building open to all
members of the Hopkins student
body. The party will start at approximately 9:30 to 10:00 p.m. according to 'Glee Club president,
John Defandorf,

Hopkins, Maryland Planning
Joint Week-end For May 21
Plans for a joint week-end of
sport and social activities centered around the Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game on May 21 are
being drawn up for submission to
the Booster Club at its next meeting.
The annual lacrosse game will
be played away this year in Maryland's Byrd Stadium. Hopkins
students who attend the game are
expected to receive a considerable
reduction of the admission price.
In addition, Hopkins has been invited to the dance which will be
held outdoors on the island facing
Maryland's fraternity row. The
dance will be admission free, and

Undergraduates of the School
of Engineering who wish to apply for state scholarship aid for
the academic year 1955-56
must file an application form
not later than April 15, 1955.
This announcement applies
to those seeking renewal as
well as to those seeking scholarship aid for the first time.

Barnstormers Draw Gast
OfForty For "Quiet Down"
The Barnstormers' coming production Quiet Down, by Joe Donahue and Pete Fischer, is drawing
its cast of nearly forty from three
schools: Hopkins, Goucher, and
The Peabody Conservatory.
Al Weinstein, president of the
club, noted that many persons not
members of the Barnstormer', especially upperclassmen, attracted
by the musical, are trying out for
the first time.
Authors Donohue and Fischer
have worked on a new script and
have revised it to strengthen the
weak points. This will be the Script
used in the production. Both members of the team have written and
produced their own dramas, for
the Barnstormers in previous
years. Bill Hunter of the Valley
Players is directing the musical.
Aaron Sopher, artist for the
Johns Hopkins Magazine, has been
attending tr youts, rehearsals,
meetings of the Barnstormers,
drawing sketches for a future feature in the publication, Weinstein
noted.

Orientation
Chairman
Prospective candidates for th4
chairmanship of Orientation Week,
1955, are urged to submit applications to the Student Council, P.O.
Box 1246, no later than March 17.
There are no specific requirements for the position other than
the applicants having previous experience with the Orientation Week
program, either as group leaders
or in some other capacity. It is
Preferred that the candidates be
in their senior year next term.
The applicants will be interviewed by the Student Council on
March 21, and the chairman will
be announced as soon as possible
after that date.
The application should have the
prospect's name and a statement
of his desire to be Orientation
Week Chairman.. There is no particular form required.
Jim Phinney, Student Council
President stated, "The chairmanship of Orientation Week is a very
important job, and I hope that
many students will think about the
position and apply for it. The
responsibilities placed upon the
chairman are quite large."
The chairman, with the assistance of Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Director of Student Activities, will
formulate the plans for the program in the ensuing months after
the selection is announced. He will
have the sole responsibility of
choosing group leaders, subject to
the final approval of the Council.
"He and Dr. Morrill will have a
very big job and will be very busy
for the next few months," said
Phinney.

Sixty-five students of the Johns
Hopkins ROTC will attend the
1955 ROTC summer camp at Fort
George G. Meade, Maryland, from
June 25 to August 5 this summer.
ROTC summer camp is a concentrated laboratory course in military science and tactics which
gives the student an opportunity
to apply the military theory learned
in the classroom. Technical operation, maintenance, and tactical employment of the latest weapons and
equipment are stressed.
Students participate in the operation of a military unit under
simulated battle conditions.

The Booster's Club has been active during the past winter and
plans to continue their beneficial
work into the future, according to
Steve Carney, president.
During the winter, the programs
for the basketball games were furnished through the efforts of the
Booster organization.
According to Carney, the organization plans to run the Home-Coming Weekend in the Spring. As
one of its parts, the weekend will
feature a float parade.
In the planning stage, Carney
stated, is the possibility of having
a Maryland-Hopkins weekend on
the weekend of the Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game, May 21. Also
under discussion, is the obtaining

of it scoreboard for baseball and
s°ccer
During the lacrosse season,
there are plans for one or more
pep rallies and possibly a caravan
to an away lacrosse game.
The Booster's Club is now in the
process of planning a University
flag. There is no such flag known
to be in existence. The need for
a school flag became apparent dur.
ing the football season when the
band requested one to carry one
in the games.

FRATERNITY BOWLING
Phi Epsilon Pi won the fraternity bowling last Saturday
afternoon by rolling 1508 in three games. Ed Goldberg and Ed
Bernstein were standouts for Phi Ep with 322 and 315 totals,
respectively.
Bruce Grimes of second-place Phi Gam had the highest individual series, with 351- Close behind were Joe Abata, of thirdplace Sig Ep, and Dick Allen, of Beta, both of whom finished with
three-games totals of 330. Abata, with a 124, had the highest sipgle
game.
The complete standings were as follows: Phi Ep, 1508; Phi
Gam, 1484; Sig Ep, 1477; Phi Psi, 1401; Beta, 1385; ATO, 1375;
KA,1351; Phi Sig, 1350; AEPi, 1293; Delta Phi, 1288; DU, 1275;
AD, 1209.
FRATERNITY PING-PONG
Phi Sig's Al Greenberg and Neil Amback upset Phi Psi's Ira
Anderson and Dick Mercer in the fraternity, ping-pong, doubles
tourney, held February 28, March 2 and 3.
Phi Sig won the first two games, 21-16, 24-22. Phi Psi fought
back with 21-17 and 21-16 victories, bringing the match into the
fifth and decisive game. Phi Sig won 21-19 taking the table -tennis
erown.

Turner Announces
Tennis Court Rules
For Levering Play
Athletic Director Marshall S.
Turner recently reannounced the
•
rules for play on the tennis courts
near Levering Hall, newly finished
late last October.
Turner noted that tennis shoes
must be worn at all times on the
courts. He also explained that the
surfaces • are private courts and
that non-University players may
be ejected—by the plant manager's
office, not the Athletic Department
—from the, courts.
The Athletic Director pointed
out that reservation-holders (undergraduate reservations may be
obtained from the Athletic Department two days ahead of the
playing date) have precedence
over other players, who may swing
a racket if they are prepared to
present a student identification
card. Those netters who have not
bothered to obtain a reservation
must give way to the reservationholders if and when the latter wish
to play.
The four dormitory courts, Turner stated, are reserved for physical
education classes and inter-collegiate play from 1 p.m. to 6 p.m.
daily.

This year the Blue Jays face

against Harvard 4 p.m., April 6.
Scott, fifth Hopkins lacrosse coach
in the past six seasons, has his
work cut out for him as he attempts to bring Hopkins back to
the national prestige it enjoyed
while winning four straight United
States college championships from
1947 through 1950.

tied one—the first non-losing slate
in four years—only one position

Prom's Attendance
Less Than Expected
"We were disappointed with the
turnout," jointly stated Mayer
Liebman, president of the Junior
Class, and Jay Yakubisin, president of the Cotillion Board, referring to last week's Junior Prom,
held at Gwynn Oak Park's Dixie
Ball Room.
• "The Cotillion Board co-sponsored the dance with the Junior
Class in order to give the student
body the opportunity to attend
a Social function with a big-name
band. HOwever, the students' response Was so disappointing, that
It is financially
impracticable to
attempt another event of this type.
Although the final figures have not
been tabulated, we estimate a loss
of approximately
$600," commented Yakubisin.
The sponsors borrowed a Johns
Hopkins University banner from
the Alumni
office to use at the
!lance. When last seen, the banDer was still hanging as a
decoration on the wall of the
Dixie Ball
Room. Liebman said,
"We feel
that the person or persons who
took the banner as
a souvenier of
the dance did not
Consider the cost
to the Junior Class and
the Cotillion Board." The banner cost approximately $100.

Military Ball
Ends Month
The Military Ball will be held in
the Homewood Gymnasium on the
evening of March 26, and it will
feature continuous music by the
Second Army Dance Band.
Tickets for the dance will go on
sale March 14 at $2.50, and tables
can be reserved at $2.00 each.
Chairman of the dance. Barrett
Kidner stated that there would be
four hundred and seventy-five tickets on sale, while three hundred
of these reserved for ROTC memtiers. Last year the dance was sold
out a week ahead of time.
Uniforms will be mandatory
dress only for the junior . and
senior members of the ROTC. Underclass members of the ROTC
are urged to\ wear uniforms, but
they are allowed to don formal
dress.
Favors will be given at the
door, and at the "commander's
cotillion" the dates of the sponsor
of the dance and the cadet colonel
will be given flowers, and the dates
of the battalion and company
commander will receive corsages.
As is in keeping with past years,
those attending the dance will not
bring corsages for their dates.
Major Joseph Spinelli is advisor
to this function, and the Pershing
Rifles and the Scabbard and Blade
are co-sponsors.

15.

Doctor McCollum
Receives Award
For Vitamin Work
Dr. Elmer V. McCollum, professor of biochemistry, Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene
and Public Health, has been given
a special Citation of Honor by the
National Dairy Council, the Society
announced.
Dr. McCollum discovered Vitamins A and B1 while teaching at
the University of Wisconsin. After
coming to Hopkins as professor of
biochemistry in 1917, he discovered
Vitamin. D. He is now research
adviser 61 the McCollum-Pratt
fund.
The citation honored Dr. McCollum especially for his discovery of
Vitamin A which "laid the foundation for an appreciation of the importance of dairy foods in human
nutrition."

Orientation
Chairman
Prospective candidates for th4
chairmanship of Orientation Week,
1955, are urged to submit applications to the Student Council, P.O.
Box 1246, no later than March 17.
There are no specific requirements for the position other than
the applicants having previous experience with the Orientation Week
program, either as group leaders
or in some other capacity. It is
Preferred that the candidates be
in their senior year next term.
The applicants will be interviewed by the Student Council on
March 21, and the chairman will
be announced as soon as possible
after that date.
The application should have the
prospect's name and a statement
of his desire to be Orientation
Week Chairman.. There is no particular form required.
Jim Phinney, Student Council
President stated, "The chairmanship of Orientation Week is a very
important job, and I hope that
many students will think about the
position and apply for it. The
responsibilities placed upon the
chairman are quite large."
The chairman, with the assistance of Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Director of Student Activities, will
formulate the plans for the program in the ensuing months after
the selection is announced. He will
have the sole responsibility of
choosing group leaders, subject to
the final approval of the Council.
"He and Dr. Morrill will have a
very big job and will be very busy
for the next few months," said
Phinney.

Sixty-five students of the Johns
Hopkins ROTC will attend the
1955 ROTC summer camp at Fort
George G. Meade, Maryland, from
June 25 to August 5 this summer.
ROTC summer camp is a concentrated laboratory course in military science and tactics which
gives the student an opportunity
to apply the military theory learned
in the classroom. Technical operation, maintenance, and tactical employment of the latest weapons and
equipment are stressed.
Students participate in the operation of a military unit under
simulated battle conditions.

The Booster's Club has been active during the past winter and
plans to continue their beneficial
work into the future, according to
Steve Carney, president.
During the winter, the programs
for the basketball games were furnished through the efforts of the
Booster organization.
According to Carney, the organization plans to run the Home-Coming Weekend in the Spring. As
one of its parts, the weekend will
feature a float parade.
In the planning stage, Carney
stated, is the possibility of having
a Maryland-Hopkins weekend on
the weekend of the Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game, May 21. Also
under discussion, is the obtaining

of it scoreboard for baseball and
s°ccer
During the lacrosse season,
there are plans for one or more
pep rallies and possibly a caravan
to an away lacrosse game.
The Booster's Club is now in the
process of planning a University
flag. There is no such flag known
to be in existence. The need for
a school flag became apparent dur.
ing the football season when the
band requested one to carry one
in the games.

FRATERNITY BOWLING
Phi Epsilon Pi won the fraternity bowling last Saturday
afternoon by rolling 1508 in three games. Ed Goldberg and Ed
Bernstein were standouts for Phi Ep with 322 and 315 totals,
respectively.
Bruce Grimes of second-place Phi Gam had the highest individual series, with 351- Close behind were Joe Abata, of thirdplace Sig Ep, and Dick Allen, of Beta, both of whom finished with
three-games totals of 330. Abata, with a 124, had the highest sipgle
game.
The complete standings were as follows: Phi Ep, 1508; Phi
Gam, 1484; Sig Ep, 1477; Phi Psi, 1401; Beta, 1385; ATO, 1375;
KA,1351; Phi Sig, 1350; AEPi, 1293; Delta Phi, 1288; DU, 1275;
AD, 1209.
FRATERNITY PING-PONG
Phi Sig's Al Greenberg and Neil Amback upset Phi Psi's Ira
Anderson and Dick Mercer in the fraternity, ping-pong, doubles
tourney, held February 28, March 2 and 3.
Phi Sig won the first two games, 21-16, 24-22. Phi Psi fought
back with 21-17 and 21-16 victories, bringing the match into the
fifth and decisive game. Phi Sig won 21-19 taking the table -tennis
erown.

its 3-2 dual meet record of last

Turner Announces
Tennis Court Rules
For Levering Play
Athletic Director Marshall S.
Turner recently reannounced the
•
rules for play on the tennis courts
near Levering Hall, newly finished
late last October.
Turner noted that tennis shoes
must be worn at all times on the
courts. He also explained that the
surfaces • are private courts and
that non-University players may
be ejected—by the plant manager's
office, not the Athletic Department
—from the, courts.
The Athletic Director pointed
out that reservation-holders (undergraduate reservations may be
obtained from the Athletic Department two days ahead of the
playing date) have precedence
over other players, who may swing
a racket if they are prepared to
present a student identification
card. Those netters who have not
bothered to obtain a reservation
must give way to the reservationholders if and when the latter wish
to play.
The four dormitory courts, Turner stated, are reserved for physical
education classes and inter-collegiate play from 1 p.m. to 6 p.m.
daily.

This year the Blue Jays face
a tough ten-game schedule, their
busiest since 1942. The opener
will be played ,at Homewood Field
against Harvard 4 p.m., April 6.
Scott, fifth Hopkins lacrosse coach
in the past six seasons, has his
work cut out for him as he attempts to bring Hopkins back to
the national prestige it enjoyed
while winning four straight United
States college championships from
1947 through 1950.
